Il Jae Lee

Student by Day, Hacker by Night.

The Story
Hacking the life one second at a time.

I was allocated into the heap in 1995.
Every since the beginning, it was clear that for me to become a useful object in this world, that my member variable must be instantiated.
And thus started my long journey to lazy-instantiate my variables.
Even though I faced various challenges such as stack overflow, null pointers and segfaults, I've overcame them all and stand here today as Il Jae Lee.

... And now, a more sane introduction for those who aren't CS majors,

As you can see from the title my name full name is Il Jae Lee (이일재 in Korean), but I usually go by Jae or J.
I was born in Seoul - however, I spent most of my childhood in the city of Auckland, and culturally identify myself as a Kiwi (slang for New Zealand people).
I'm a self-taught programmer who initially started programming in hopes of creating a video game.
That interest evolved into a passion to create something that can bring an impact in the world (Check out some of the stuff I've made over here).
Other than programming, I enjoy snow/skateboarding (although I suck), spending time with my rabbit (you can check out a video of him here), drawing, eating sushi and teaching others.

I'm currently enrolled in Cranbrook Kingswood, Class of 2015.

I love programming. I love solving new challenges. I love designing stuff with beauty and functionality in mind.
Don't I sound like a good fit for the job?

Major Projects
Stuff that I'm really proud of.

Round & Round (2011.8 ~ 2012.9)

Round & Round was the first video game I've ever attempted to create.
I started the project as soon as I enrolled in Cranbrook Kingswood as a freshman (so around 3~4 years ago.).
There I was, fresh with my knowledge of C++, bought a copy of the Leadwerks Engine, and started hacking.
Over-ambitious and not very well planned out, the project did not see completion. Nevertheless, I value the experience as it has taught me a lot about programming and project management in general, and most importantly I had tones of fun in the process.

You can the game in action over here:
WIP Video / Tech Demo

moon.chase.star (2013.1~2013.5)

moon.chase.star is a rapid game I've developed over a period of 4 months.
Even though I've given up on completing Round & Round, I've decided to pursue the idea of a simple ball-game.
In order to meet the development schedule, I've also cut down on some of the features I had in mind, simplified the whole art asset by switching from 3D to 2D, and chosen a mono-color theme.
I've also built LEAP Motion controller integration for the first MHacks 2013, and placed in the top 10.

It was released successfully on Desura.
The source code has also been released.
Since launch, the game has been downloaded over 10,000 times.

GimmeGlasses (Weekend Hack)

The idea was simple - when a user provides an image, 'hipsterize' it.
GimmeGlasses is a site I've launched after a weekend of hacking, where a user may upload a selfie, then the serverside logic detects the face and places glasses on their face.
This was my first web project, and I've learnt a lot about web programming and server management.
For the image recognition and processing, I've used OpenCV.

QMark (MHacks 2013 Winter)

QMark was the hack I've made at the 2nd MHacks.
After being fed up with managing bookmarks thousands of bookmarks, I've decided to build a better way to manage them.
When a user registers a bookmark, QMark automatically scans the page for the most important keywords and phrases.
User then can search through the bookmarks by only typing keywords - no need to remember the full name or URL!

The source code for this project has been released, although this was my first Django project and don't suggest anyone to reference the code I wrote for QMark.

Segment

Bored during summer break, I've made Segment game.
The gameplay is a clone of the IGF Winner Perfection.
I've basically cloned the whole game in a matter of 7 days - the length of my stay at Samsung Medical Hospital for a surgery.
Written in C++, using Cocos2D-x.

The source code for this project has been released.
Or watch the gameplay video.

WhiteBox (Weekend Hack)

WhiteBox is a weekend hack I made where it answers a user's questions.
User may ask a question, which then the natural language parser processes the question to build an MQL Query.
The query is then passed into Freebase to find the answer.
Heavily inspired by Wolfram Alpha.

Readly.IO

Readly.IO is a project where I attempted to solve the problem of one-time article consumption.
People read tons of articles through major news sites, blogs, publishing platforms such as Medium and so on.
However, whats important to realize is that those consumptions are happening only once - while repeated reading is the key factor to memorization.
That's the goal of Readly.IO - to remind people to revisit the articles they've read.
When people tweet about an article they enjoyed, Readly.IO instantly puts the article on its queing list, and sends out an email when its appropriate.
Due to the explosive popularity over a short amount of time, the app exceeded Twitter API's max request, and had to be closed down.

For anyone who is interested in continuing the service, source code is available here.
